ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: You read books that you'll sort of base your discussion on, but in reality just talk about how we should best live our lives. It's sort of pseudo-intellectual, but it was enjoyable nonetheless. Take it, of course.
Definitely take it! Courses with accomplished, real-world-experienced professors are exactly what make the Global Affairs major great.
Take it. You will start to question yale and your life choices and it's not particularly hard. Only 2 paper.

Not sure how hard to get into this class, but if you get in it is a must take. If you're a senior as I was, this class will challenge you in so many ways, especially if your entire Yale career, like mine, was focused more on obscure fields than tackling the larger life questions.

One of the most enriching classes I have taken in four years at Yale. A wonderful set of readings, class discussions were very engaging, and Professor Brooks offers a unique combination of breadth of perspective and depth of insight. Highly recommend.
Famous, distinguished professor. Some of the smartest students at Yale. A reading list that is really important to finish. Not a very academic course but a very good one. Take it if you can.
Humility is an awesome class to take regardless of what you are studying. It's particularly interesting for people who want to do more thinking about religion, philosophy, theology, and ethics.

My most commonly recommended class the opportunity have discussions about what matter to us and in life and how we interact with our world is invaluable. Thank you so much for the opportunity to be part of the discussion!
